item.title: Turkey Widens Purge as Crackdown Continues
item.media:description: A funeral in Ankara, Turkey, on Monday for one of the victims of the recent coup attempt.
item.description: The Interior Ministry fired nearly 9,000 police officers on Monday, officials said, coming after the arrests of 6,000 military personnel and suspensions of nearly 3,000 judges.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: E.U. and U.S. Urge Erdogan to Show Restraint After Coup Attempt in Turkey
item.media:description: Bodyguards surrounded President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center, as he attended the funeral of a victim of the coup attempt in Istanbul on Sunday.
item.description: Even before the weekend’s events, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had represented a quandary for E.U. foreign ministers, who are meeting in Brussels.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Erdogan Triumphs After Coup Attempt, but Turkey’s Fate Is Unclear
item.media:description: Women prayed at a mosque in Ankara, Turkey, during funeral ceremonies on Sunday for those killed over the weekend. Mosques played a crucial role in mobilizing citizens to stop the uprising.
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s victory over the uprising may have bolstered his popularity among Islamists, but wider support was not yet certain.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Many Turks Prefer Even Flawed Democracy to Coup
item.media:description: A crowd mourning Sunday at a mosque in Ankara, Turkey, with relatives of members of the military and the police who were killed during the attempted coup.
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.description: After the attempted overthrow of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, there was a sense of relief in Istanbul, and Sunday was a day of pro-government rallies and funerals.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Turkey Allows Resumption of U.S. Missions From Incirlik Air Base
item.media:description: Incirlik Air Base in Adana, Turkey, last year.
item.media:credit: Ibrahim Erikan/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: The missions by American warplanes flown from Turkey against Islamic State targets were shut down in the hours after the failed coup in the nation.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: In Istanbul, Optimism Fades to a Familiar Melancholy
item.media:description: A pro-government demonstration in Istanbul on Sunday. It was in Istanbul that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan consolidated his power in the aftermath of a failed coup.
item.description: The coup attempt showed Istanbul to be perhaps Turkey’s most important city, but it is enveloped by a deep unease about terrorism, refugees and gentrification.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Attack in Nice Turns Spotlight on City’s Religious Divisions
item.media:description: Samih Abid, a longtime resident of Nice, said he fears the “soft discrimination” he has felt will harden.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Muslims and non-Muslims have lived alongside each other in Nice for generations, but last week’s massacre has exacerbated tensions among residents.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: In the Age of ISIS, Who’s a Terrorist, and Who’s Simply Deranged?
item.description: Instances of wanton violence have been swiftly judged to be the work of terrorists, even when there is little evidence of direct ties to terrorist groups.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Nigeria Finds a National Crisis in Every Direction It Turns
item.media:description: Fuel trucks stranded near the main highway of Warri, Nigeria, last month after militants calling themselves the Niger Delta Avengers disrupted fuel distribution.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: President Muhammadu Buhari promised to stamp out terrorism in the north and to rebuild the economy. But the nation now faces terrorism, separatism and low oil prices.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta

item.title: Iran’s President Is Confronted by Scandal Over Inflated Government Wages
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, wearing a turban, in Parliament in January. He is facing a scandal involving inflated salaries for managers and executives of state-run companies.
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani is enduring a storm over disclosures showing astronomical bonuses and salaries paid to managers of state-run companies.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Gunman Stages Deadly Attack on Police Station in Kazakhstan
item.media:description: Police officers detained a suspect in an armed attack at a police station in Almaty, Kazakhstan, on Monday.
item.description: Three officers and a civilian were killed in Almaty, the country’s largest city, in an assault described as blending criminal and radical Islamist motivations.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Top South Korean Prosecutor Arrested on Charges He Accepted Bribes
item.description: Accused of taking payment from an online game maker, the official, Jin Kyung-joon, is the most senior Korean prosecutor ever arrested while in office.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

item.title: Memo From Brazil: Interim President’s Poems Take Hold of Brazilians, but Not in a ‘Fiery Flames’ Way
item.media:description: The poetry of Michel Temer, Brazil’s interim president, has become a welcome distraction for Brazilians in the midst of political turmoil.
item.description: Amid political turmoil, the poetry of Michel Temer has become a welcome source of amusement — and offers insight into the man now at the country’s helm.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Trilobites: South African Telescope Spots 1,300 Unknown Galaxies
item.media:description: Left: A patch of sky about as big as the full moon where the MeerKAT telescope discerned the radio glow of about 200 galaxies. Only a few (circled) had been previously observed; Right: A distant galaxy that is being blown up by a black hole at its center.
item.description: The distant galaxies were recorded by a set of 16 antennas that will eventually be a part of the largest telescope ever built on Earth.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: 4 Kenyan Policemen Charged in Deaths of Lawyer, Client and Driver
item.description: The three men vanished after the lawyer, Willie Kimani, filed a complaint on behalf of his client, Josphat Mwenda, alleging that he had been shot and wounded by the police.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Attacker in Nice, France, Looked for Articles on Orlando and Dallas Attacks
item.description: Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, 31, who killed 84 people in a rampaging truck, also had searched for Islamist information in the two weeks before the attack.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Hostage Standoff at Yerevan Police Building in Armenia Enters 2nd Day
item.media:description: Officers securing the area around a police building in Yerevan, Armenia, on Sunday that was attacked by militants. Five people are believed to be held hostage.
item.media:credit: Aram Kirakosyan/PAN photo, via Associated Press
item.description: Militants, who are possibly holding five people, demanded that the government resign and that it release an opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Abroad in America: An International Reader’s Guide to the Republican Convention
item.media:description: Workers preparing Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland, where the convention will be held, on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: A look at the American election by a Times foreign correspondent, approaching the topic in much the same way as we would events overseas, deciphering the action for a global audience.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: With Pokémon Go, Nintendo Seeks to Salvage Lost Opportunity
item.media:description: A Pokémon character on a street in London during a game of Pokémon Go. The augmented-reality game came about because Nintendo has gone years without a hit and was forced to find partners.
item.description: Nearly two decades ago, the video game company released a forerunner to today’s game that foreshadowed much of mobile gaming. Then it lost its lead.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Amsterdam Journal: Beyond Anne Frank: The Dutch Tell Their Full Holocaust Story
item.media:description: A monument at the National Holocaust Museum in Amsterdam. Anne Frank’s diary has long been the dominant narrative of the Netherlands’ experience during the Holocaust, but the Dutch are trying to tell a more complete story of the Nazi occupation.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: A memorial wall and a new Holocaust museum reflect a push in the Netherlands to give a more complete understanding of what happened under Nazi occupation.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: 3 More Reported Held in Bastille Day Truck Attack in Nice
item.media:description: Flowers placed over the blood of a victim at a makeshift memorial where a man drove a truck through a crowd in Nice, France.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: They were the latest of seven people detained after the attack, French news media said, as the 84 deaths were marked on the second of three days of national mourning.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: John Kerry Rejects Suggestions of U.S. Involvement in Turkey Coup
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry in Moscow on Friday, the day of an attempted coup in Turkey.
item.description: “We think it’s irresponsible to have accusations of American involvement,” the secretary of state said.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: What in the World: Visiting Madagascar? Leave Red Swimsuits (and Lemur Recipes) at Home
item.media:description: Behavior in Madagascar is governed by thousands of cultural taboos, or fady, that may seem random and superstitious to outsiders.
item.description: Thousands of cultural taboos, or fady, are crucial to the identity and worldview of the Malagasy, but may seem random and superstitious to outsiders.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: What in the World: Never Mind Grass-Fed, How About Elixir-Fed Meats?
item.description: In China, meat from livestock fed on traditional herbal remedies fetches a premium price from health-conscious shoppers.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: When the Planets Align, Delhi Drowns in a Chorus of ‘I Do’
item.media:description: Guests dancing at a wedding in New Delhi on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Vivek Singh for The New York Times
item.description: A certain astrological configuration is considered auspicious by many Indians, and in the capital it means something very specific: a wedding apocalypse.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Editorial: The Countercoup in Turkey
item.description: While Turkish citizens appear to have chosen democracy, the man they kept in power is working hard against a democratic society.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Editorial: Mr. Obama’s Dubious Detention Centers
item.description: These privately run, unlicensed lockups are no place for children.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Turkey’s Coup That Wasn’t
item.description: A failed coup in Turkey does not mean democracy is the winner. In fact Erdogan may now undermine democracy further.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: As Refugee Family Resettles in Sweden, 9-Year-Old Nephew Dies
item.media:description: While a nurse prepares a medicine, Nabih, 9, rests in a hospital bed next to an aunt, his brother Farid and his mother Shazia Nouri, right, at a hospital in Antalya, southern Turkey.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Ahmad Majid is one of millions of people swept up in a global refugee crisis; his resettlement in Sweden ended when his young nephew died this week.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
